dcterms:title: Identifying and Transplanting Younger Hematopoietic Stem Cells to Alleviate Aging Phenotypes
dcterms:abstract: Aging is a process accompanied by functional decline in tissues and organs with great social and medical consequences. Developing effective anti-aging strategies is of great significance. In this study, we demonstrated that transplantation of young hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) into old mice can mitigate aging phenotypes, underscoring the crucial role of HSCs in the aging process.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Introduction
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: The aging process is marked by a functional decline across various tissues and organs, significantly increasing the risk for a multitude of chronic diseases.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Methods
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: Young and old HSCs were sorted and transplanted into recipient mice to assess rejuvenation effects.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Results
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: CD150lowHSCs exhibited improved engraftment compared to CD150highHSCs and extended lifespan in old recipient mice.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Discussion
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: Our findings indicate a potential strategy for rejuvenation via targeted removal of dysfunctional CD150highHSCs.

cito:cites.dcterms:title: Blood-borne revitalization of the aged brain
